A Study of the Edge-Switching Markov-Chain Method for the Generation of Random Graphs

Alexandre O. Stauffer
Valmir C. Barbosa

Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
Programa de Engenharia de Sistemas e Computação, COPPE
Caixa Postal 68511
21941-972 Rio de Janeiro - RJ, Brazil Corresponding author (valmir@cos.ufrj.br).
Abstract

We study the problem of generating connected random graphs with no self-loops or multiple edges and that, in addition, have a given degree sequence. The generation method we focus on is the edge-switching Markov-chain method, whose functioning depends on a parameter w𝑤witalic_w related to the method’s core operation of an edge switch. We analyze two existing heuristics for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w during the generation of a graph and show that they result in a Markov chain whose stationary distribution is uniform, thus ensuring that generation occurs uniformly at random. We also introduce a novel w𝑤witalic_w-adjusting heuristic which, even though it does not always lead to a Markov chain, is still guaranteed to converge to the uniform distribution under relatively mild conditions. We report on extensive computer experiments comparing the three heuristics’ performance at generating random graphs whose node degrees are distributed as power laws.


Keywords: Random-graph generation, Edge switch, Markov chain.

We consider in this paper the problem of generating graphs of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly at random when D𝐷Ditalic_D is realizable.

In the absence of the connectivity constraint, the problem of generating random graphs for a given degree sequence is closely related to some other problems, like generating a (0,1)01(0,1)( 0 , 1 ) matrix with given marginals [25], approximating the permanent of a matrix [19], and sampling a perfect matching or an f𝑓fitalic_f-factor of a graph [14, 5]. However, it remains generally unknown how to generate graphs uniformly at random for a given degree sequence within reasonable time bounds [26], even though exceptions exist for some special cases, like regular [21] and bipartite graphs [14, 19].

The problem of generating random graphs has recently acquired considerable prominence from a practical perspective. Since many real-world networks, like the Internet, the WWW, social networks, and scientific-collaboration networks, typically have a very large number of nodes and have evolved over time in such an unorganized way that only limited information is known about their topologies [3, 24], many studies of their properties have been conducted within a random-graph framework [2, 15]. In addition, these networks are now known to differ sharply from the classical random-graph model introduced by Erdős and Rényi [12, 8], in which the node-degree distribution is the Poisson distribution. Some empirical studies suggest that many of them have node-degree distributions that seem to conform to a power law [13, 6, 3, 24], that is, the probability that a randomly chosen node has degree a𝑎aitalic_a is proportional to a−τsuperscript𝑎𝜏a^{-\tau}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_τ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some τ>1𝜏1\tau>1italic_τ > 1.

Clearly, any method for sampling a graph uniformly at random from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a given D𝐷Ditalic_D can be easily extended to generate random graphs having a power-law node-degree distribution. We first obtain D𝐷Ditalic_D by sampling each djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the power-law distribution. If D𝐷Ditalic_D turns out not to be realizable, then we discard it entirely and obtain a new one, repeating this process while needed. We then select the desired graph uniformly at random from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Other, more complex methods for generating random graphs having node degrees distributed as a power law have been proposed. In these methods, generation is achieved by successively adding nodes and edges to the graph in such a way that tries to follow some principles, like preferential attachment, that are believed to have guided the evolution of some real-world networks [22, 9]. However, simply generating a graph having a given degree sequence sampled from the power-law distribution has been observed to perform satisfactorily with regard to certain measures [27]. Moreover, this approach can be used to obtain random graphs having any node-degree distribution, which is an important flexibility since correctly determining the node-degree distribution of real-world networks has remained essentially an open problem [1].

Given a realizable D𝐷Ditalic_D, we consider the generation method that we call the edge-switching Markov-chain (ESMC) method for choosing graphs from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly at random, also variously known by other denominations [16]. This method, which can be modeled as a Markov chain and whose details are more thoroughly described in Section 2, employs an operation that we call an edge switch to transform a graph of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into another graph, maybe not in 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by virtue of not being connected, that has the same degree sequence D𝐷Ditalic_D. Let G𝐺Gitalic_G be the graph being generated. To avoid generating unconnected graphs, we periodically perform a connectivity test on G𝐺Gitalic_G. If G𝐺Gitalic_G is unconnected, we undo all the edge switches performed since the previous connectivity test. Basically, the method consists of first obtaining a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT deterministically and then applying a series of edge switches and connectivity tests to G𝐺Gitalic_G until a certain halting condition is satisfied. We also discuss in Section 2 a methodology for obtaining the halting condition, which ultimately also embodies a criterion for estimating how close G𝐺Gitalic_G is to a uniformly random sample from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The ESMC method is intrinsically based on an integer parameter w≥1𝑤1w\geq 1italic_w ≥ 1 giving the number of edge switches to be attempted between successive connectivity tests. Naturally, setting w𝑤witalic_w appropriately is crucial to the performance of the method. When w𝑤witalic_w is too small, a large number of connectivity tests is performed, which dramatically increases the running time of the method, as the time complexity of a connectivity test is high in comparison to the time complexity of an edge switch. On the other hand, when w𝑤witalic_w is excessively large the probability that the connectivity test is performed on an unconnected graph tends to be high, possibly causing many edge switches to be undone. Obtaining an ideal value for w𝑤witalic_w beforehand seems to be an elusive goal, so heuristics have been proposed for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w along the algorithm’s execution [16, 29]. We discuss the existing heuristics, and also introduce a new one, in Section 3.

We present in Section 4 the results of extensive computer experiments for degree sequences sampled from power-law distributions. We evaluate the three heuristics described in Section 3 along with two different halting conditions. In general, our computational results indicate that, on average, our heuristic outperforms the two existing heuristics in terms of the total running time by a margin of 12%percent1212\%12 % to 86%percent8686\%86 %. We conclude in Section 5.

2 The ESMC method

We henceforth denote by G𝐺Gitalic_G the graph being generated, that is, the graph on which the edge switches and the connectivity tests are performed. An edge switch is performed on a pair of nonadjacent edges (i.e., edges that share no nodes) and consists of removing them from G𝐺Gitalic_G and adding back one of two other pairs of edges. The pair of edges to be added to G𝐺Gitalic_G is chosen at random from these two and the edge switch is only carried through if neither edge of the chosen pair already exists in G𝐺Gitalic_G. For example, let (uj,uk)subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑘(u_{j},u_{k})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (ux,uy)subscript𝑢𝑥subscript𝑢𝑦(u_{x},u_{y})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be two nonadjacent edges of G𝐺Gitalic_G. The edge-switching operation on (uj,uk)subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑘(u_{j},u_{k})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (ux,uy)subscript𝑢𝑥subscript𝑢𝑦(u_{x},u_{y})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) consists of removing these edges from G𝐺Gitalic_G and adding to G𝐺Gitalic_G either (uj,ux)subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑥(u_{j},u_{x})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (uk,uy)subscript𝑢𝑘subscript𝑢𝑦(u_{k},u_{y})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) or (uj,uy)subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑦(u_{j},u_{y})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (uk,ux)subscript𝑢𝑘subscript𝑢𝑥(u_{k},u_{x})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Although node degrees are clearly seen to remain unchanged by an edge switch, G𝐺Gitalic_G may become an unconnected graph. Figure 1(a) illustrates the two possible edges switches on the edges (uj,uk)subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑘(u_{j},u_{k})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (ux,uy)subscript𝑢𝑥subscript𝑢𝑦(u_{x},u_{y})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Figure 1(b) illustrates a situation in which only one edge switch can be carried through on those edges.

The ESMC method is best described on a Markov chain ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M having one state associated with each graph of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If G1,G2,…,G|𝒢D|subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2…subscript𝐺subscript𝒢𝐷G_{1},G_{2},\ldots,G_{\left|{\cal G}_{D}\right|}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the graphs in 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and X1,X2,…,X|𝒢D|subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋subscript𝒢𝐷X_{1},X_{2},\ldots,X_{\left|{\cal G}_{D}\right|}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the states of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M, then we let, for 1≤i≤|𝒢D|1𝑖subscript𝒢𝐷1\leq i\leq\left|{\cal G}_{D}\right|1 ≤ italic_i ≤ | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the state in which G=Gi𝐺subscript𝐺𝑖G=G_{i}italic_G = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In essence, the ESMC method consists of initially obtaining a graph of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then performing a sequence of transitions on ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M from the corresponding state until a certain halting condition is satisfied.

In order to obtain the initial graph, we employ the Havel-Hakimi algorithm [18, 17, 7], which successively adds edges to an initial graph G𝐺Gitalic_G having n𝑛nitalic_n isolated nodes. For 1≤j≤n1𝑗𝑛1\leq j\leq n1 ≤ italic_j ≤ italic_n, along the process let the residual degree rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the difference between djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the number of edges already incident to ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; clearly, rj=djsubscript𝑟𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗r_{j}=d_{j}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT initially. The algorithm repeatedly selects the node, say uksubscript𝑢𝑘u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, having the highest residual degree and connects it to the rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes having the next highest residual degrees, which leads to rk=0subscript𝑟𝑘0r_{k}=0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 and also to smaller values of the other nodes’ residual degrees. The repetition goes on until rj=0subscript𝑟𝑗0r_{j}=0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all j𝑗jitalic_j such that 1≤j≤n1𝑗𝑛1\leq j\leq n1 ≤ italic_j ≤ italic_n. At this moment, G𝐺Gitalic_G has degree sequence D𝐷Ditalic_D but may be unconnected. Since D𝐷Ditalic_D is realizable, G𝐺Gitalic_G must contain a cycle if it is not connected. If we take an edge of this cycle and an edge of another connected component, and perform an edge switch on them, then necessarily two of the connected components of G𝐺Gitalic_G are merged together into a single one. This process can be repeated until G𝐺Gitalic_G becomes connected.

Let us then describe what constitutes a transition in ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M. Let w≥1𝑤1w\geq 1italic_w ≥ 1 be an integer parameter. A transition in ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a sequence of w𝑤witalic_w steps that we call edge-switching attempts. In each edge-switching attempt, we randomly select two distinct edges of G𝐺Gitalic_G. If they are not adjacent, then we randomly choose one of the two possible edge switches. If the chosen edge switch is feasible, that is, it does not involve adding an edge that already exists in G𝐺Gitalic_G, then we go on and perform the edge switch. G𝐺Gitalic_G is kept unchanged otherwise. After w𝑤witalic_w edge-switching attempts, we perform a connectivity test on G𝐺Gitalic_G. If G𝐺Gitalic_G turns out to be unconnected, then we undo all the edge switches performed during the previous w𝑤witalic_w edge-switching attempts.

Now let m𝑚mitalic_m be the number of edges of G𝐺Gitalic_G. If we use an array with the edges of the graph, an adjacency matrix, and an appropriate collection of incidence lists and pointers, then an edge switch can be done in O⁢(1)𝑂1O(1)italic_O ( 1 ) time while requiring Θ⁢(n2)Θsuperscript𝑛2\Theta(n^{2})roman_Θ ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) space, which for large n𝑛nitalic_n is prohibitive. An alternative way is to use an array with the edges of the graph and an appropriate collection of incidence trees and pointers, which leads to O⁢(log⁡d1)𝑂subscript𝑑1O(\log d_{1})italic_O ( roman_log italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) time and Θ⁢(m)Θ𝑚\Theta(m)roman_Θ ( italic_m ) space instead. This has been our choice in all the computer experiments we discuss in Section 4. In any case, and considering that the connectivity test can be performed in O⁢(m)𝑂𝑚O(m)italic_O ( italic_m ) time, setting w𝑤witalic_w properly is essential to the achievement of good performance. We return to this issue in Section 3.

The main results that pertain to the use of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M in sampling a random graph from 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly at random are consequences of the following two classic theorems on Markov chains [20, 23].

Theorem 1.

A finite, irreducible, and aperiodic Markov chain converges to a unique stationary distribution regardless of the initial state.

Theorem 2.

Corollary 3, given next, follows directly from Theorem 2.

Corollary 3.

3 Heuristics for parameter adjustment

As we remarked at the end of Section 1, adjusting w𝑤witalic_w along the evolution of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a viable alternative, aiming at better convergence properties, to fixing its value at the onset. In this section we discuss some heuristics to do this. Each transition consists now of performing w𝑤witalic_w edge-switching attempts, a connectivity test (with the ensuing possible undoing of all the edge switches performed during the w𝑤witalic_w attempts), and moreover an update of the value of w𝑤witalic_w. We consider two approaches to adjusting w𝑤witalic_w. The first consists of a mechanism that is used in all existing heuristics for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w in accordance with the result of the previous connectivity test. The other one is a new heuristic that adjusts w𝑤witalic_w aiming at approximating a given probability for the success of the next connectivity test. Notice that, in either case, Corollary 4 is no longer applicable and the convergence of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M has to be re-examined.

3.1 Two current heuristics

Let us begin with the first approach. We start with w=1𝑤1w=1italic_w = 1 and increase the value of w𝑤witalic_w whenever the connectivity test succeeds; we decrease it otherwise. As we demonstrate next, a Markov chain exists associated with this approach that has a uniform stationary distribution.

Two heuristics for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w based on the outcome of the connectivity test have been proposed. In the first heuristic, which is a variation of the one introduced by Gkantsidis, Mihail, and Zegura in [16] and is henceforth referred to as the GMZ heuristic, w𝑤witalic_w is updated to w+1𝑤1w+1italic_w + 1 when the connectivity test is successful and to ⌈w/2⌉𝑤2\lceil w/2\rceil⌈ italic_w / 2 ⌉ otherwise.111The original heuristic in [16] differs from this variation in two ways. First, it forces the probability of remaining at the same state after a transition to be at least 0.50.50.50.5; secondly, the choice of the two edges to undergo a switch is restricted to nonadjacent edge pairs only. However, by adopting our variation of the heuristic, which lets adjacent edge pairs be chosen as well, the probability of remaining at the same state is automatically reinforced. The other heuristic, due to Viger and Latapy [29] and henceforth referred to as the VL heuristic, is based on two parameters, q+superscript𝑞q^{+}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and q−superscript𝑞q^{-}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that q+>0superscript𝑞0q^{+}>0italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 and 0<q−<10superscript𝑞10<q^{-}<10 < italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1. It prescribes that w𝑤witalic_w be updated to (1+q+)⁢w1superscript𝑞𝑤(1+q^{+})w( 1 + italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_w when the connectivity test succeeds and to (1−q−)⁢w1superscript𝑞𝑤(1-q^{-})w( 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_w otherwise. In [29] it is suggested that these two parameters be adjusted in such a way as to satisfy q+/q−=e−1superscript𝑞superscript𝑞𝑒1q^{+}/q^{-}=e-1italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_e - 1. We report on computer experiments with these two heuristics in Section 4.

3.2 A new heuristic

Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α be such that 0<α<10𝛼10<\alpha<10 < italic_α < 1. We introduce a new heuristic to adjust w𝑤witalic_w whose goal is to achieve a constant probability α𝛼\alphaitalic_α for the success of the next connectivity test. The new heuristic relies on a special connectivity test, whose details are described in Appendix A, that not only checks whether G𝐺Gitalic_G is connected but also calculates the probability that G𝐺Gitalic_G remains connected after an edge-switching attempt. We refer to this new heuristic as the SB heuristic.

For 1≤i≤|𝒢D|1𝑖subscript𝒢𝐷1\leq i\leq\left|{\cal G}_{D}\right|1 ≤ italic_i ≤ | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, let ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the probability that Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains connected after an edge-switching attempt. The SB heuristic is based on the assumption that the probability that a connectivity test succeeds after w𝑤witalic_w consecutive edge-switching attempts starting at Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (ρi)wsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑤(\rho_{i})^{w}( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other words, we assume that the probability that a graph remains connected after each of the w𝑤witalic_w edge-switching attempts is ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and also that it suffices that one single edge switch yields an unconnected graph in order for the next connectivity test to be unsuccessful. We note that the latter assumption makes special sense under power-law node-degree distributions, since in such cases random node deletions are not likely to split the graph into more than one relatively large connected component [4, 10]. What this means is that, when an edge switch renders the graph unconnected, the forthcoming connectivity test can only succeed if a subsequent edge switch is performed on edges from different connected components, that is, most likely on at least one edge belonging to a relatively small connected component, which is a low-probability event.

In order to obtain ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we calculate the number of pairs of edges of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on which performing an edge switch generates an unconnected graph. Clearly, an edge switch can only make Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unconnected if the two edges involved in the switch constitute a cut of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (3)

In Appendix A we give a connectivity test that calculates the value of ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and is asymptotically no harder than depth-first search in the worst case.

If Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the graph obtained right after a connectivity test, then the intuition behind the SB heuristic indicates that w𝑤witalic_w should be adjusted in a way that led to α=(ρi)w𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑤\alpha=(\rho_{i})^{w}italic_α = ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, yielding

w=ln⁡αln⁡ρi.𝑤𝛼subscript𝜌𝑖w=\frac{\ln\alpha}{\ln\rho_{i}}.italic_w = divide start_ARG roman_ln italic_α end_ARG start_ARG roman_ln italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (4)

Notice, however, that each graph Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may have a different ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so the Markov chain modeling this method might converge to a stationary distribution that is different from the uniform distribution. For this reason, we define ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ) to be the average of every ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obtained right after each of the first t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1 connectivity tests (the initial one and the t𝑡titalic_t others that correspond to transitions). We then let the SB heuristic adjust w𝑤witalic_w according to

w=⌈ln⁡αln⁡ρ¯⁢(t)⌉𝑤𝛼¯𝜌𝑡w=\left\lceil\frac{\ln\alpha}{\ln\bar{\rho}(t)}\right\rceilitalic_w = ⌈ divide start_ARG roman_ln italic_α end_ARG start_ARG roman_ln over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_ARG ⌉ (5)

right after the t𝑡titalic_tth connectivity test. Note, in connection with (5), that w𝑤witalic_w is assuredly a positive integer. Furthermore, for the reasons discussed in Section 3.1, we limit w𝑤witalic_w by a fixed upper bound W𝑊Witalic_W.

We remark, finally, that as a consequence of w𝑤witalic_w being adjusted as a function of every ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ever obtained, the method cannot be modeled as a Markov chain and, to be rigorous, can no longer even be treated as a variation of the ESMC method in which another heuristic is used. However, if ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ) converges as t→∞→𝑡t\to\inftyitalic_t → ∞, then w𝑤witalic_w also converges. In this case, w𝑤witalic_w approaches a constant and, as noted in Section 2, we once again have a method that can be modeled as a Markov chain having a uniform stationary distribution. In Section 4, our approach to assessing the convergence of ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ) (and of w𝑤witalic_w, consequently) is to compare the average value of g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) at the end of an execution under the SB heuristic to those obtained under the GMZ and VL heuristics. As we demonstrate in that section, the figures for the SB heuristic vary within relatively small percentages with respect to those of either of the other two heuristics and we take this as indication that ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ) is close to convergence. In what follows, then, we continue to refer to the SB heuristic as an alternative for use with the ESMC method.

4 Computational results

In this section we present computational results for the three heuristics of Section 3. We have concentrated on power laws with τ=2.0,2.1,…,3.0𝜏2.02.1…3.0\tau=2.0,2.1,\ldots,3.0italic_τ = 2.0 , 2.1 , … , 3.0 and set n=103𝑛superscript103n=10^{3}italic_n = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. All experiments were carried out on a Pentium 4HT running at 3GHz with 1GB of main memory. All running times we report refer to total elapsed times under a Linux operating system hosting one single user.

Before discussing our experiments, we pause momentarily to elaborate on a curious behavior of the power-law distribution. From Section 1, we know that, in order for D𝐷Ditalic_D to be realizable, its average node degree must be no less than the average node degree of a tree, which is approximately 2222 for sufficiently large n𝑛nitalic_n. For n=103𝑛superscript103n=10^{3}italic_n = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, this is expected to hold only for τ⪅2.47𝜏2.47\tau\lessapprox 2.47italic_τ ⪅ 2.47, meaning that for τ⪆2.47greater-than-or-approximately-equals𝜏2.47\tau\gtrapprox 2.47italic_τ ⪆ 2.47 D𝐷Ditalic_D is expected not to be realizable. By requiring realizability as we repeatedly sample D𝐷Ditalic_D from the power law, we are in fact making the node-degree distribution be slightly different from that very power law. What we have observed is that, for τ⪆2.47greater-than-or-approximately-equals𝜏2.47\tau\gtrapprox 2.47italic_τ ⪆ 2.47, the node-degree variance for realizable degree sequences tends to increase with τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ while the number of edges remains roughly constant. These characteristics have affected the results we present next very strongly.

In our experiments, we used W=104𝑊superscript104W=10^{4}italic_W = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For each value of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, we sampled 600600600600 realizable degree sequences and, for each of them, executed the generation method using the three heuristics and two distinct halting conditions. We carried out the VL heuristic for q+=0.1,0.2,0.3superscript𝑞0.10.20.3q^{+}=0.1,0.2,0.3italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.3 and set q−superscript𝑞q^{-}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in such a way that q+/q−=e−1superscript𝑞superscript𝑞𝑒1q^{+}/q^{-}=e-1italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_e - 1. The SB heuristic was carried out for α=0.1,0.2,0.3𝛼0.10.20.3\alpha=0.1,0.2,0.3italic_α = 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.3.

We have focused on analyzing four indicators, each calculated from the 600600600600 executions with each heuristic and each halting condition. The first one, which we denote by Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the ratio of the average g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) value at the end of an execution to the average value of g¯⁢(t)¯𝑔𝑡\bar{g}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_t ) also at the end of an execution. Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be used as a source of information on the convergence of the Markov chain, as we know that g¯⁢(t)¯𝑔𝑡\bar{g}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_t ) is an unbiased estimator for g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ). Generally, the deviation of Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from 1111 grows with how far the generated graph is from a uniformly random sample of 𝒢Dsubscript𝒢𝐷{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The second indicator, which we denote by Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the average number of edge switches performed during an execution that are not undone as a result of the connectivity test. The third indicator, which we denote by Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the average value of w𝑤witalic_w at the end of an execution. The last indicator, finally, is the average running time (in minutes) of an execution and is denoted by Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4.1 Halting on the clustering coefficient

For the first halting condition, we have let g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) be the clustering coefficient of G𝐺Gitalic_G. This coefficient is the ratio of three times the number of triangles in G𝐺Gitalic_G to the number of three-edge paths in G𝐺Gitalic_G (each triangle corresponds to three such paths) [24]. Calculating the clustering coefficient requires O⁢(d1⁢m)𝑂subscript𝑑1𝑚O(d_{1}m)italic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ) time, as a triangle is identified by checking whether an edge’s end nodes have a common neighbor. We have used δ=60𝛿60\delta=60italic_δ = 60 and γ=10−4𝛾superscript104\gamma=10^{-4}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for this halting condition.

With regard to our discussion at the end of Section 3.2 on the convergence of ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ), we have observed the average value of g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) under the SB heuristic to vary within only roughly 5%percent55\%5 % of the values obtained for the GMZ heuristic for most values of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, the exceptions being τ=2.4𝜏2.4\tau=2.4italic_τ = 2.4 (7.8%percent7.87.8\%7.8 %) and τ=2.5𝜏2.5\tau=2.5italic_τ = 2.5 (6.3%percent6.36.3\%6.3 %). As for the VL heuristic, the percentage drops to roughly 3%percent33\%3 %, the exceptions being the same with 5.7%percent5.75.7\%5.7 % for τ=2.4𝜏2.4\tau=2.4italic_τ = 2.4 and 5%percent55\%5 % for τ=2.5𝜏2.5\tau=2.5italic_τ = 2.5.

Figure 3 shows the results obtained with this halting condition for the GMZ heuristic (parts (a–d)), the VL heuristic (e–h), and the SB heuristic (i–l). The plots for Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 3(a, e, i)) show that Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to 1111 for all the three heuristics, especially when τ≤2.1𝜏2.1\tau\leq 2.1italic_τ ≤ 2.1 or τ≥2.8𝜏2.8\tau\geq 2.8italic_τ ≥ 2.8. The plots for Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 3(b, f, j)) show that the smallest value of Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained for τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4, suggesting that the clustering coefficient converges faster for such a value of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. The parameters q+superscript𝑞q^{+}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and q−superscript𝑞q^{-}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the VL heuristic and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of the SB heuristic seem, curiously, to have small impact on Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, since m𝑚mitalic_m is almost constant for τ≥2.5𝜏2.5\tau\geq 2.5italic_τ ≥ 2.5, Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not seem to be proportional to m𝑚mitalic_m, as assumed in the analysis conducted in [29] for a slightly different power law. The plots for Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 3(c, g, k)) show that the smallest value of Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also obtained when τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4, indicating that the probability that an edge-switching attempt results in an unconnected G𝐺Gitalic_G is smaller when τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4. We note that the highest Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained with the SB heuristic. The reason for this behavior seems to be that both the GMZ heuristic and the VL heuristic start with w=1𝑤1w=1italic_w = 1, while the SB heuristic starts with w𝑤witalic_w relatively close to Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The plots for Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 3(d, h, l)) show that the SB heuristic yields on average the smallest running time, despite employing a more complex connectivity test. For example, the SB heuristic has on average outperformed the GMZ heuristic by roughly 12%percent1212\%12 % when τ=2.0𝜏2.0\tau=2.0italic_τ = 2.0, 44%percent4444\%44 % when τ=2.3𝜏2.3\tau=2.3italic_τ = 2.3, 61%percent6161\%61 % when τ=2.6𝜏2.6\tau=2.6italic_τ = 2.6, and 74%percent7474\%74 % when τ=3.0𝜏3.0\tau=3.0italic_τ = 3.0. In comparison to the VL heuristic, these figures have been roughly 21%percent2121\%21 % when τ=2.0𝜏2.0\tau=2.0italic_τ = 2.0, 25%percent2525\%25 % when τ=2.3𝜏2.3\tau=2.3italic_τ = 2.3, 51%percent5151\%51 % when τ=2.6𝜏2.6\tau=2.6italic_τ = 2.6, and 56%percent5656\%56 % when τ=3.0𝜏3.0\tau=3.0italic_τ = 3.0. Regarding the value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, the smallest average Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the SB heuristic corresponds to α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1italic_α = 0.1. We expect Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to decrease even more if we continue decreasing α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, but this decrease will probably be progressively smaller until an optimal value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is achieved. Also, it is curious to note that, for τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ near 3.03.03.03.0, the GMZ heuristic yields the smallest Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but the highest Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in comparison to the other heuristics. In this situation, Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is so small that, even performing substantially fewer edge switches, the ESMC method requires on average much longer to conclude.

Figure 4(a) presents the average μibsubscriptsuperscript𝜇b𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the end of an execution for the SB heuristic when the halting condition is based on the clustering coefficient. The value of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ for which we obtain the highest average is 2.42.42.42.4, in accordance with the fact that Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is on average minimum for this same value (cf. Figure 3(c, g, k)). When τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is decreased from 2.42.42.42.4, on average μibsubscriptsuperscript𝜇b𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases as well, since the graph is expected to have more edges and, consequently, fewer bridges. When τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is increased from 2.42.42.42.4, on average μibsubscriptsuperscript𝜇b𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also decreases. The reason in this case is that, since the number of edges remains practically constant as τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is increased from 2.42.42.42.4, and moreover the variance within the degree sequence increases, the graph tends to acquire several star-like subgraphs and therefore the fraction of adjacent or neighbor bridge pairs is expected to increase. Figure 4(b) refers to μicsubscriptsuperscript𝜇c𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{c}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The behavior is similar, albeit in an extremely smaller scale, thus indicating that the fraction of nonadjacent, non-neighbor pair cuts in graphs whose node degrees are power-law-distributed is on average negligible. If we ignore pair cuts and use ρi=1−μibsubscript𝜌𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝜇b𝑖\rho_{i}=1-\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 - italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in lieu of (3), then we obtain figures for Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as shown in Figure 4(c). Since for small d1subscript𝑑1d_{1}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the time complexity of calculating the clustering coefficient is relatively close to the time complexity of a connectivity test, speeding-up the connectivity test impacts more strongly the overall running time. For example, when τ=2.4𝜏2.4\tau=2.4italic_τ = 2.4, in which case we have observed the value of d1subscript𝑑1d_{1}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be relatively small on average, ignoring pair cuts leads to a decrease in Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of about 31%percent3131\%31 % on average. 4.2 Halting on the average distance between nodes

The second halting condition is based on letting g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) be the average distance between the nodes of G𝐺Gitalic_G, which can be calculated by conducting a breath-first search rooted at each node of G𝐺Gitalic_G. This calculation requires Θ⁢(n⁢m)Θ𝑛𝑚\Theta(nm)roman_Θ ( italic_n italic_m ) time, therefore more than the calculation of the clustering coefficient. We have used δ=30𝛿30\delta=30italic_δ = 30 and γ=10−3𝛾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for this halting condition.

As we once again return to the issue raised at the end of Section 3.2 on the convergence of ρ¯⁢(t)¯𝜌𝑡\bar{\rho}(t)over¯ start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ( italic_t ), for this second halting condition we have observed the average value of g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) under the SB heuristic to stay below roughly 1%percent11\%1 % of the values obtained for the GMZ heuristic for all values of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. As for the VL heuristic, the percentage remains the same but for τ=2.1𝜏2.1\tau=2.1italic_τ = 2.1 (1.8%percent1.81.8\%1.8 %).

Figure 5 shows the results when this is the halting condition for the GMZ heuristic (parts (a–d)), the VL heuristic (e–h), and the SB heuristic (i–l). The plots for Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 5(a, e, i)) show that Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is relatively far from 1111 in comparison to the results obtained with the first halting condition (Figure 3(a, e, i)). In order to obtain Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT closer to 1111, we may need to increase δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ and/or decrease γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. Despite being not so close to 1111, the value of Rconvsubscript𝑅convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is almost the same regardless of which heuristic is used to adjust w𝑤witalic_w. The plots for Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 5(b, f, j)) show that the smallest value of Rswitchsubscript𝑅switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occurs when τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4. Similarly to the case of the clustering coefficient, this suggests that the average distance between nodes converges faster when τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4.222This agreement of the three heuristics under either halting condition may in fact be indicative that the ESMC method itself converges faster for this value of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. The plots for Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 5(c, g, k)) also show that the smallest Rwsubscript𝑅𝑤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained for τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4. Regarding Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 5(d, h, l)), the plots show that the SB heuristic leads once again to the smallest running time on average. For example, on average the SB heuristic outperforms the GMZ heuristic by roughly 77%percent7777\%77 % when τ=2.0𝜏2.0\tau=2.0italic_τ = 2.0, 86%percent8686\%86 % when τ=2.3𝜏2.3\tau=2.3italic_τ = 2.3, 85%percent8585\%85 % when τ=2.6𝜏2.6\tau=2.6italic_τ = 2.6, and 75%percent7575\%75 % when τ=3.0𝜏3.0\tau=3.0italic_τ = 3.0. In comparison to the VL heuristic, on average the SB heuristic outperforms it by roughly 41%percent4141\%41 % when τ=2.0𝜏2.0\tau=2.0italic_τ = 2.0, 80%percent8080\%80 % when τ=2.3𝜏2.3\tau=2.3italic_τ = 2.3, 82%percent8282\%82 % when τ=2.6𝜏2.6\tau=2.6italic_τ = 2.6, and 54%percent5454\%54 % when τ=3.0𝜏3.0\tau=3.0italic_τ = 3.0. The average gain obtained with the SB heuristic is higher under this halting condition, which can be explained by noting that each transition is now slower than under the halting condition based on the clustering coefficient. As a consequence, it is under the average-distance halting condition that the impact of adjusting w𝑤witalic_w properly is more strongly manifest. Also, and unlike what occurs with the first halting condition, the gain obtained with the SB heuristic is now higher when τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is around 2.42.42.42.4. This suggests that the choice for g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) depends on a careful consideration of each application’s peculiarities. Regarding the value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, the SB heuristic once again leads to the smallest Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1italic_α = 0.1, suggesting that the optimal value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is less than 0.10.10.10.1.

Figure 6 presents, respectively in parts (a) and (b), the average μibsubscriptsuperscript𝜇b𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and μicsubscriptsuperscript𝜇c𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{c}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the SB heuristic when the halting condition is based on the average distance between nodes. The results are similar to the ones shown in Figure 4(a, b) for the halting condition based on the clustering coefficient. The plots for Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Figure 6(c)), on the other hand, show a very different behavior. For almost all values of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is now seen to increase slightly when pair cuts are ignored. The reason for this behavior seems to be an insufficient number of samples. In fact, we expect Rtimesubscript𝑅timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be very slightly smaller than that obtained when pair cuts are not ignored. Since the time complexity of calculating the average distance between nodes is significantly higher than that of a connectivity test, ignoring pair cuts is therefore expected to have a small impact on the overall running time of the method.

5 Conclusions

We have considered the problem of generating, uniformly at random, connected graphs that have a given degree sequence but no multiple edges or self-loops. We studied the ESMC method, which employs edge switches to transform a graph into another while preserving the degree sequence. This method consists of first deterministically finding a graph with the desired properties and then performing random edge switches and also connectivity tests to obtain a randomized result.

We showed that, if we attempt to perform a constant number w𝑤witalic_w of edge switches between successive connectivity tests, then the method can be modeled as a Markov chain having a uniform stationary distribution. We also showed that, if w𝑤witalic_w is not constant but rather is adjusted as a function of the last connectivity test’s outcome, then the method can still be modeled as a Markov chain of uniform stationary distribution.

We have also introduced a new heuristic for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w that depends on the probability that the graph being generated remains connected after an edge switch is attempted. In order to calculate this probability, we use a new connectivity test that has the same time and space complexities as depth-first search (cf. Appendix A). Even though the resulting method cannot always be modeled as a Markov chain, we showed that there are circumstances under which it too converges to the uniform distribution.

One of the main issues regarding generation methods based on Markov chains is determining the number of transitions to be performed until the Markov chain is satisfactorily close to its stationary distribution. We have approached this issue by resorting to the pragmatic procedure of computing, after each transition, a certain function of the graph being generated, and halting the generation when the average of this function over all transitions seems to have converged. A proper choice for this function is essential to the efficacy of the method, but appears to require consideration on a case-by-case basis.

We have given computational results for power-law-based degree sequences. Our results contemplate two previous heuristics for adjusting w𝑤witalic_w and also our new heuristic, and were given for two distinct halting criteria. They show that our heuristic, on average, outperforms the two existing heuristics on power laws for which 2≤τ≤32𝜏32\leq\tau\leq 32 ≤ italic_τ ≤ 3.

The ESMC method can be especially useful to generate a group of connected random graphs having the same degree sequence. After obtaining the first graph, we can continue performing a relatively small number of transitions to generate each additional instance, without having to run the method from its beginning. Finally, the ESMC method can be extended to generate random graphs having a given degree sequence and another desired property (e.g., graphs having the clustering coefficient limited to a given interval). We need only find a means of obtaining an initial graph having that property, then obtain an efficient procedure to test whether a graph has that property, and also show the irreducibility of the Markov chain, that is, show that there is a sequence of edge-switching attempts connecting any two graphs having the given degree sequence and the desired property.

A.1 Handling bridge pairs

A.2 Handling pair cuts

The number of nonadjacent, non-neighbor pair cuts, which is the basis for computing μicsubscriptsuperscript𝜇c𝑖\mu^{\mathrm{c}}_{i}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, can be obtained by calculating the number of pair cuts, the number of adjacent pair cuts, and the number of neighbor pair cuts. Two edges of Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT form a pair cut if and only if they are covered by one single common back edge (e.g., (u1→u2)→subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2(u_{1}\to u_{2})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (u4→u5)→subscript𝑢4subscript𝑢5(u_{4}\to u_{5})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in Figure 7). In order to identify pair cuts during the search, for each node we store the back edge that connects either the node itself or one of its descendants to its lowest-level ancestor. If more than one back edge reaches the same node, then we need store neither, since no edge through which the search is yet to backtrack can be uniquely covered by any of them.

A.3 Complexity

Let us now discuss the space and time complexities of this modified depth-first search. Clearly, the ESMC method requires Ω⁢(m)Ω𝑚\Omega(m)roman_Ω ( italic_m ) space, since we need to store an array with the edges of the graph being generated. During the search, for each node uksubscript𝑢𝑘u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we need to store its parent (say, ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), its level, the Bksubscriptsuperscript𝐵absent𝑘B^{\mathrm{}}_{k}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s, and the back edge covering (uj→uk)→subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑢𝑘(u_{j}\to u_{k})( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) that reaches the lowest-level node.
